node.title: Reef scientists anxiously eyeing the weather as QLD, WA face potential bleaching events
node.description: Bleaching-free coral reefs are expected to plummet as we head towards 1.5C of warming, as scientists anxiously watchÂ for another bleaching event on the Great Barrier Reef.
node.content:
["The number\u00a0of coral reefs worldwide that will be spared the harm of warming is predicted to plummet within just a few decades.", "That's the finding\u00a0of research published today in the journal PLOS Climate, which comes as reef scientists \"anxiously\" eye off the potential for\u00a0bleaching events on the Great Barrier Reef and in Western Australia over the coming weeks.", "Currently about 84 per cent of the world's coral reefs are buffered from ocean warming by influences like cool upwellings, deep water,\u00a0and cooler ocean currents.", "But today's\u00a0research shows that figure will drop to just 0.2 per cent of reefs when global warming breaches 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels.", "We're currently forecast to hit 1.5C in the 2030s, and it's believed that there's now almost no chance of staying under that limit without extremely aggressive cuts to emissions and unproven carbon capture\u00a0technologies\u00a0that can draw CO2 from the atmosphere.", "The Great Barrier Reef suffered bleaching events in 2016, 2017, and 2020,\u00a0and the co-author of today's paper, Scott\u00a0Heron from James Cook University, said scientists were anxiously watching weather patterns in Queensland's north, and off the northern WA coast.", "", "
Scientists are anxiously watching conditions in the Great Barrier Reef.(Getty Images: Brett Monroe Garner)
", "\"Here we are at the end of January \u2014 summertime in Australia \u2014 and we're seeing heat stress developing to a point of potential widespread coral stress on the Great Barrier Reef,\" Dr Heron\u00a0said.", "Some overcast monsoonal weather has given the reef a brief reprieve from the heat, and scientists are hoping for more of the same to stave off yet another catastrophic hit just two years after the last, Dr Heron said.", "But there are already signs of\u00a0corals fluorescing \u2014 a sign of distress in some species \u2014 and some whiteness has been observed, according to marine biologist Jodie Rummer from JCU.", "She says temperatures are already high and if there are cumulative days of heating over the next weeks or months, bleaching is likely to occur.", "\"We've got temperatures\u00a0that are warmer\u00a0than expected [and] there's\u00a0not as much mixing [of water] as we'd hoped,\u00a0despite it being a La Nina,\" Dr Rummer said.", "Marine biologist Mike van Keulen from Murdoch University in Perth says there are already \"signs of coral stress\" in north-west Western Australia as well.", "Warm waters in the north can cause coral stress down much of the WA coastline, Dr van Keulen says.", "\"Particularly for WA, that\u00a0becomes a problem because the warm water to the north of us seeds the Leeuwin current that runs down our coast.", "\"The last big event we had in 2011 bleached corals\u00a0all the way down to Rottnest Island [off Perth].\"", "
At 2C, no reef\u00a0will be spared
", "In order to understand the future of coral reefs globally, Dr Heron and colleagues\u00a0from the University of Leeds and Texas Tech University\u00a0modelled the impact of warming on reefs\u00a0down to a resolution of 1 square kilometre.At 1.5C of warming, they found\u00a0only a few reefs in Polynesia and the Coral Triangle in the western Pacific would be spared recurring \"thermal stress events\" at least once\u00a0every 10 years, according to\u00a0Dr Heron.", "\"There were very few places around\u00a0the world [that would be spared]\u00a0and they were focused in the area of French Polynesia and the Coral Triangle,\" he\u00a0said.", "", "
Many of the more delicate and colourful corals will disappear as we\u00a0head towards 1.5C of warming.(Getty Images: Colin Baker)
", "The scientists found that more than 90 per cent of reefs will suffer these thermal stress events at least every five years.", "Thermal stress events are\u00a0periods of elevated sea-surface temperature capable of causing \"significant coral bleaching\".", "No reefs in Australia will be immune to regular thermal stress events once warming reaches 1.5C, they concluded.", "At 2C of warming, no reefs worldwide will be spared the impact of climate change.", "Today's findings, and the prospect of yet another bleaching event, underline how important climate action is for the reef, Dr Rummer said.", "\"All of these secondary and tertiary issues the reef is facing, it's not going to matter if we fix them without addressing the real problem, which is\u00a0climate change,\" she said.", "A number of scientists, including Dr Rummer, were critical of last week's pledge by the\u00a0federal government\u00a0for $1 billion over nine\u00a0years for the reef, without also committing to ambitious climate action.", "Dr van Keulen says\u00a0programs that will be funded under the government's pledge, which are aimed at improving the\u00a0resilience of corals, are \"too little, too late\".", "\"We've got climate change that\u00a0causes consecutive years of bleaching;\u00a0there's no way we can return to normal from here.", "As we approach 1.5C, Dr van Keulen says the delicate, colourful corals we associate with tropical holidays will be gone.", "As they go, we will see \"huge flow-on effects\" in fish abundance and\u00a0diversity, which will also impact many commercial industries like seafood and tourism.", "Dr Heron says the more we study the impacts of climate change on reefs, the more we realise we're heading toward a \"cliff face\"."]
